messages.content: What are the benefits of using Docker?

Docker provides: 1) Consistency across environments (works the same on dev, test, prod), 2) Isolation (dependencies don't conflict), 3) Fast deployment, 4) Easy scaling, 5) Version control for environments. It packages your app with all dependencies into containers.
How is it different from a virtual machine?

Docker containers share the host OS kernel, making them lightweight (MBs vs GBs) and fast to start (seconds vs minutes). VMs include a full OS copy, providing stronger isolation but using more resources. Containers are better for microservices; VMs for complete OS-level isolation.

A Dockerfile is a text file with instructions to build a Docker image. It specifies the base image (FROM), copies files (COPY), runs commands (RUN), sets environment variables (ENV), exposes ports (EXPOSE), and defines the startup command (CMD). Think of it as a recipe for your container.
Can you give a basic Dockerfile example?

Basic Python app Dockerfile: FROM python:3.9; WORKDIR /app; COPY requirements.txt .; RUN pip install -r requirements.txt; COPY . .; EXPOSE 8000; CMD ['python', 'app.py']. This creates an image with Python, installs dependencies, copies your code, and runs the app.
